awd_titl_txt: Chemical Dynamics of Organic Peroxy Radicals at Aerosol Particle Interface
awd_abstract_narration:
This award from the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the NSF Division of Chemistry supports Professor Haofei Zhang at the University of California, Riverside to study organic aerosol (OA) particles. Atmospheric OA affect the Earth’s climate in crucial but poorly understood ways. The uncertainty is largely due to the complex chemical processes that constantly change OA compositions during their lifetime of weeks. Professor Zhang and his group study the chemical reactions of organic peroxy radicals (RO2) at the surfaces of the particles. These chemical processes largely determine the chemical composition and physiochemical properties of the particle interface. Better knowledge of the details of these reactions improves our understanding of the evolution and impacts of OA. Other broader impacts of this project include the training and mentoring of undergraduate and graduate students, especially those from the underrepresented groups. In addition, Professor Zhang leads outreach activities with Riverside high schools that serve minority students and participates in a summer academy program aimed at enhancing STEM education for diverse students.

The project focuses on the heterogeneous hydroxyl radical oxidation of OA proxies and the subsequent pathways of RO2 at the OA particle interface. This includes the previously under-explored RO2 + hydroperoxyl radical, RO2 + nitric oxide, RO2 dimerization, and RO2 autoxidation reactions. Laboratory oxidation experiments are performed using a hybrid continuous-flow reaction system. This provides information on the relative importance of the various RO2 reaction pathways. The different pathways are impacted by the OA composition, liquid water content, oxidation timescales, and oxidant concentrations. The team uses a suite of advanced mass spectrometry instrumentation to systematically study the oxidation kinetics and the chemical composition of key oxidation products. A multiphase reaction-diffusion kinetic model framework representing the interfacial RO2 processes of interest is being developed. The model is based on experimental results and presents a crucial extension to the current understanding of radical-initiated OA heterogeneous oxidation mechanisms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Atmospheric organic aerosols play a crucial but poorly understood role in affecting the Earth’s radiative balance. The uncertainty is largely due to the complex chemical processes that constantly evolve organic aerosols during their lifetime. Many of these processes are initiated from the multiphase interactions between gas-phase oxidants such as the hydroxyl radicals (OH) and organic aerosol particles at the interface. However, in traditional studies, this multiphase oxidation chemistry has mainly focused on peroxy radical (RO2) cross reactions that form a pair of carbonyl and alcohol products or alkoxy radicals (RO). In this project, we performed experimental and modelling investigations to examine various additional pathways of RO2 at the particle interface that have not been explored previously, including RO2 + hydroperoxyl radical (HO2), RO2 + nitric oxide (NO), dimerization from RO2 + RO2 reactions, and RO2 isomerization.

We utilized a suite of state-of-the-art instrumentation to measure the chemical composition of organic aerosols through OH-initiated multiphase oxidation. Over a dozen of different organic aerosol model systems were studied, comprised of functional groups often seen in atmospheric aerosols such as alcohol, carbonyl, and carboxylic acid. These organic aerosol model systems are moderately to highly oxidized, representative of those commonly reported in atmospheric aerosols.  We performed the oxidation reactions in two customized laboratory reactors to control the key factors that govern or affect the RO2 dynamic pathways. The examined key factors include relative humidity, oxidant concentrations (OH and HO2), the presence of NO, the presence of inorganic components, and reaction timescales. Furthermore, we developed a multilayer reaction-diffusion kinetic model to describe and simulate the performed experiments to gain more kinetic and quantitative insights into the dynamic RO2 pathways.

Overall, the results of this research project demonstrated that during OH-initiated chemical evolution of organic aerosols, highly dynamic and diverse RO2 reactions occur and lead to complex oxidation production. Specifically, we reported that when HO2/OH concentration raised to atmospheric levels, the RO2+HO2 reactions occurring at the aerosol particle interface could play a significant role that lead to the formation of organic hydroperoxides (ROOH) and RO that facilitate organic aerosol evolution. We also found that RO2 + NO reactions take place at the aerosol particle interface that leads to the formation of organic nitrates, which could potentially serve as a sink and reservoir of atmospheric reactive nitrogens. Moreover, we showed that when inorganic components co-exist with the organic aerosol species, the oxidation of organic aerosols gets faster under both low and high relative humidity but due to different mechanisms. The presence of inorganics is also suggested to affect the chemical pathways especially those for RO. Lastly and importantly, we reported for the first time, the occurrence of RO2 bimolecular autoxidation in the particle phase, which efficiently cycles RO2 and accelerates organic aerosol chemical aging. This chemistry occurs via RO2 reacting with a closed-shell organic species rather than another radical and forming ROOH. We find that organic aerosol OH-oxidation may be 2 – 3 orders of magnitude faster through this mechanism when the OH radicals are at atmospheric levels. Direct laboratory measurements and kinetic simulations were coupled to demonstrate this result. With autoxidation, we estimate that the organic aerosol oxidation timescale in the atmosphere may be only a few hours. Thus, heterogeneous oxidation of organic aerosols can have more significant atmospheric and climate impacts than previously expected. Furthermore, our findings reveal the nature of heterogeneous aerosol oxidation chemistry in the atmosphere and may reconcile the discrepancies between atmospheric observations and laboratory studies on organic aerosol aging. This result opens up new avenues for heterogeneous organic aerosol oxidation to play key roles in various atmospheric processes. We also suggest that autoxidation can lead to organic aerosol oxidation throughout the entire aerosol particle even for highly viscous OA, rather than confined at the gas-particle interface, as previously understood.

Finally, as part of this project, we incorporated our research findings into undergraduate and graduate chemistry courses, and provided research, networking, and educational outreach opportunities to train the next generation of STEM leaders, including graduate students, undergraduate students, and postdoctoral scholars. They were provided with opportunities to work as a team in the research group, report scientific findings at national and international conferences, and serve as authors in scientific publications.
